quizzes.title: History Quiz: Pencils and Pencil
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, terrorists, cannery. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This famous American writer wrote all of the novel Cannery Row in pencil. He claimed to have used 60 pencils a day for his writings.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Steinbeck

questions.question: What was the occupation of The Greatest American Hero, according to the TV show?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: High school teacher

questions.question: A great step forward in the world of pencils was made in 1858. What was it?

options.text: Sears-Roebuck began selling pencils in their catalog.
Hyman Lipman began putting an eraser on the end of pencils.
Sarah Teasdale Wallace patented the first indelible pencil.
Irving Kellogg Watson patented the first drawing pencils in different colors.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hyman Lipman began putting an eraser on the end of pencils.

questions.question: Approximately how many pencils are sold annually in the USA?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 2,000,000,000

questions.question: Which of these is not among the reasons for which most pencils are yellow?

options.text: To show that they come from China
To make them easier to see on a desk top
To show that they are top quality
To copy the style of the first pencils made in the USA

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: To copy the style of the first pencils made in the USA

questions.question: In what year were pencils first mass-produced?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1662 A.D.

questions.question: If your pencil has a  reddish brown grain and a smell, what does that usually indicate?

options.text: It is made of rainforest wood.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: It is made of  incense-cedar.

questions.question: Who is P.L. Travers most famous literary character?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mary Poppins

questions.question: What event did the terrorists target in the 1977 movie Black Sunday?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Super Bowl

questions.question: What happened in the pencil world in 1822?

options.text: The eraser was put onto the pencil.
Pencils were made with clips to hold onto a  pocket.
Pencils that wrote in different colors were made.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The mechanical pencil was invented.

questions.question: According to the popular song, in what city is the House of the Rising Sun located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New Orleans

questions.question: Which of these is a real event  in the history of the pencil?

options.text: The discovery of rubber in Malaysia in 1823
The discovery of lead in what is now Turkey, ca. 573 A.D.
The discovery that cedar wood has three times the tensile strength of any other wood
The discovery of graphite in Seathwaite, Burrowdale, England

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The discovery of graphite in Seathwaite, Burrowdale, England

questions.question: Who was the famous American writer  whose first job was selling and making pencils?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry David Thoreau

questions.question: In the first manned rocket flights into space, pencils, not pens, were given to the cosmonauts and astronauts. Why?

options.text: They were less dangerous because they contained no metal.
Pencils can write in zero gravity.
They were less affected by lower amounts of oxygen.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pencils can write in zero gravity.

questions.question: If your pencil has a pinkish grain and little or no smell, then it is probably made from which substance?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: plastic

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Movies and Actor
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, people. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This actor, whose autobiography was called My Wicked Wicked Ways, starred in the movies Adventures of Robin Hood (1938), Istanbul (1957) and They Died with Their Boots On (1941).
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Errol Flynn

questions.question: Which of Henry VIII’s wives outlived him?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Catharine Parr

questions.question: What movie popularied the phrase Make My Day?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sudden Impact

questions.question: How tall is Chicago’s Sears Tower?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1453 ft (443 m)

questions.question: An albatross can fly all day without flapping its wings.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: On TV, what was the name of Sergeant Prestons horse?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rex

questions.question: According to a popular 1960s slogan, where would you meet the nicest people?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: On a Honda

questions.question: What 1951 film did Humphrey Bogart win an Oscar for?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: African Queen

questions.question: There is no country in the world whose name begins with this letter of the alphabet.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: X

questions.question: What was Shakespeares last play?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Tempest

questions.question: What color is Johnnie Walkers jacket?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Red

questions.question: What substance do South American Indians use on the tips of their poison darts?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: curare

questions.question: The ending of what Steven Spielberg movie takes place at Devils Tower?

options.text: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

questions.question: Which of these movies did not win 11 Academy Awards?

options.text: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Braveheart

questions.question: The hands and feet have the most bones in the human body.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Country and Role
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, mascot. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of these US states is not named after a river?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Iowa

questions.question: According to Leonardo da Vinci the color green represented what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: water

questions.question: What country has a plain green flag?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Libya

questions.question: Which of these cities is not a capital of a country in the European Union?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Zurich

questions.question: Emerald is the birthstone for this month.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: May

questions.question: Which of the following battles was not fought during World War Two?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of Jutland

questions.question: Which of these is not  a prime number?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1

questions.question: According to legend, each leaflet of a 4-leaf clover has a meaning. What does the 1st leaf mean?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hope

questions.question: In the movie The Green Mile, Tom Hanks plays Paul Edgecomb, but he was not the first choice for the role. Who was originally considered for the role?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Travolta

questions.question: Wally the Green Monster is the mascot for which sports team?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Boston Red Sox

questions.question: The ancient Roman Empire stretched from modern day Great Britain to Egypt. Which present day country was not part of the Roman Empire?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Poland

questions.question: The flag of which of the countries listed below is not red and white?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jamaica

questions.question: Which of the following people was not awarded the Nobel Peace Prize?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Paul II

questions.question: Which of these is not an American writer?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joseph Conrad

questions.question: Which of these is not an actual name of a sea?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Blue Sea

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Fear and Phobia
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, people, kind. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which world denotes a phobia of a small rodent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Musophobia

questions.question: This phobia forces people indoors.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Heliophobia

questions.question: The Hundred Years War -- a series of related conflicts between France and England, started in 1337 and lasted how many years?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 116

questions.question: Arrange the listed phobias in the following order: fear of clowns, fear of speaking in public, fear of smells, fear of needles.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Coulrophobia, Glossophobia, Osmophobia, Trypanophobia

questions.question: Three of the following terms mean one and the same thing - fear of storms. Which is the forth one that is related to sleep?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Clinophobia

questions.question: In the 1957 movie classic, 12 Angry Men, after a preliminary vote it becomes clear that only one of the jurors, Davis, does not see the open and shut nature of the case.  What is Davis juror number and what is his profession?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Juror #8, an architect

questions.question: Zoophobias are some of the most widespread abnormal fears. Which of the following is not a fear associated with animals?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neophobia

questions.question: The Green Lantern is a Marvel comics superhero with a power ring which enables him to control the physical world for as long as his willpower allows.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which word refers to the fear of long words?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hippopotomonstrosesquippedaliophobia

questions.question: What does a person who has a gymnophobia fear?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nudity

questions.question: What album was released by the rock band Weezer in 2001?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Green Album

questions.question: Which of the following terms refers to the fear of being buried alive?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Taphephobia

questions.question: Which of the following words is a synonym of paraskevidekatriaphobia (fear of Friday the 13th)?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Friggatriskaidekaphobia

questions.question: What kind of person is described by the expression green around the gills?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Physically ill

questions.question: Which of the following words is related to phobias?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Irrationality

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Boeing and 747
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, augusta, stars. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: According to Luke 6:13, Jesus called unto him his disciples, and of them he chose twelve, whom also he named apostles.  Which one did Jesus not choose?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mark

questions.question: The Boeing 747 project was so big, that there were no buildings that could house it.  Boeing constructed the largest building in the world for this purpose.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The total assembly of the Boeing 747 would require how many individually numbered and catalogued parts?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 4 000 000

questions.question: The Boeing 747 project was bankrolled by the President of an airline company, when in 1965 a downpayment of $250,000,000 was made.  Which was the airline company?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pan American

questions.question: To build the 747, The Boeing Co. needed to design and construct a large number of tools.  Approximately how many?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 270 000

questions.question: Until its replacement by the EMS scale, the Medvedev-Sponheuer-Kárník scale was the most commonly applied scale in Europe, used to measure what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Earthquake intensity

questions.question: In the Spring of 1967, this city was 700 acres of rock and timber.  In a little more than 6 months it would be transformed in a high-tech city.  It was comissioned by a company, whose mission was simple - to build the biggest and fastest subsonic commercial jetliner ever constructed.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Everett, Washington

questions.question: Buddhism, a religion and philosophy based on the teachings of Siddhārtha Gautama, traces its origins to which country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: India

questions.question: Listen to the audio and name the performer.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: David Bowie

questions.question: How many stars are there on the flag of New Zealand?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 4

questions.question: German-born princess, Sophie Augusta Fredericka of Anhalt-Zerbst, reigned as Empress of what country, from June 28, 1762 until her death?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Russia

questions.question: The first 747 was due to roll out of the production line in which year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1969

questions.question: The incredibles was a term used during the production of 747 referring to what?

options.text: The airlines which put downpayments and helped jumpstart the project
The significant others of the workers

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The rugged team of workers

questions.question: In 1867, Alfred Nobel introduced the first Pyrotechnic Fuse blasting cap, using what primary explosive to detonate dynamite?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mercury fulminate

questions.question: Name the legislative branch of the federal government of the United States.

options.text: The Congress of the United States

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Congress of the United States

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Person and Statement
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, freud, kind. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which list contains the three species of Zebras?

options.text: gray zebra, red zebra, plains zebra
mountain zebra, savannah zebra, southern zebra
Garveys zebra, Darwins zebra, gray zebra
Grevys zebra, plains zebra, mountain zebra

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Grevys zebra, plains zebra, mountain zebra

questions.question: This Scottish engineer was the first person to demonstrate a working television.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Logie Baird

questions.question: Who had Solomons wisdom, Hercules strength, Atlas stamina, Zeus power, Achilles courage, and Mercurys speed?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Captain Marvel

questions.question: Who was the first guest host on NBCs Saturday Night Live?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Carlin

questions.question: In what year did Freud and his collaborator, Josef Breuer publish Studies on Hysteria, a book which contained a number of Breuer and Freuds case studies of hysterics, including their most famous case - Anna O.?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1895

questions.question: What do Ronald Reagan, King Henry VIII, Charles Lindbergh, Jerry Stiller, Mel Brooks, and William Shakespeare have in common?

options.text: Each can trace his genealogy to Germany.
Each had a sibling named Jane.
Each was married to a woman named  Anne.
Each one was born in a  year ending in a 9.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Each was married to a woman named  Anne.

questions.question: This person, who in 1919 became the General Manager of Radio Corporation of America (RCA), claimed  that he was the first person to receive a signal from the sinking Titanic in 1912.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: David Sarnoff

questions.question: Which famous writer introduced the term moron into everyday vocabulary?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Moliere

questions.question: Who was the first  guest on The Tonight Show  when Johnny Carson was the host?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Groucho Marx

questions.question: The tail assembly of 747 stands the height of a building of approximately how many stories?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: approx. 6 stories

questions.question: Which statement is not correct?

options.text: Kermit the Frog spoke at the funeral of ventriloquist Edgar Bergen.
A cord of wood is 128 cubic feet of wood.
Isaac Van Amburgh is given credit as the first performer to put his head into the mouth of a  living lion.
James Bartley was swallowed whole by a whale, but was rescued and lived another 35  years.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: James Bartley was swallowed whole by a whale, but was rescued and lived another 35  years.

questions.question: The 747 was the second airplane designed with a cockpit above the deck.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Which statement is false?

options.text: FDR is famous for saying Nothing is so much to be feared as fear.
O.Henry  founded a humorous weekly paper named The Rolling Stone.
Henry David Thoreau is famous for saying Nothing is so much to be feared as fear.
Tennessee Williams was born in Mississippi.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: FDR is famous for saying Nothing is so much to be feared as fear.

questions.question: Three of these statements are urban legends. Which is the true statement?

options.text: Jackie Robinson was court-martialed because he would not sit in the back of a military bus.
The life span for a tiger in captivity is the same as it is in nature.
Based on the writings in his diaries, Abner Doubleday is given credit for inventing the rules of modern baseball.
Jackie Robinson won the first Rookie of the year Award in 1947.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jackie Robinson won the first Rookie of the year Award in 1947.

questions.question: The original 747  was fitted with what kind of jet engines?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pratt  Whitney JT9D-3
